name: Donu Arapura
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Donu Arapura is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in algebraic geometry and Hodge theory. His extensive research includes topics such as the geometry of cohomology support loci, mixed Hodge structures, and the study of fundamental groups of algebraic varieties. Arapura has published numerous influential papers in prestigious journals, contributing significantly to the understanding of Hodge cycles, vanishing theorems, and the interplay between algebraic geometry and topology. He is also involved in mentoring students and has delivered various talks and lectures on advanced mathematical concepts.

name: Saugata Basu
title: Professor of Mathematics and Computer Science
research_description: Saugata Basu is a prominent researcher and educator in the field of mathematics, currently focusing on real algebraic and o-minimal geometry, model theory, combinatorics, and computational complexity theory. He has co-authored the second edition of "Algorithms in Real Algebraic Geometry" and has edited several volumes on discrete and computational geometry. Basu is actively engaged in the academic community, organizing and participating in numerous conferences and workshops, including upcoming events at prestigious institutions. His extensive publication record includes significant contributions to the understanding of Betti numbers, semi-algebraic sets, and algorithms in algebraic geometry, reflecting his influence in both theoretical and applied mathematics.

name: Steven Bell
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Steven R. Bell is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he engages in teaching and research across various mathematical disciplines. His current research interests and contributions to the field are reflected in his numerous publications, although specific topics are not detailed in the provided text. Bell is actively involved in mentoring students at different academic levels, offering guidance in courses ranging from introductory to advanced mathematics. He also plays a role in enhancing departmental resources and support for students, demonstrating his commitment to both education and the mathematical community.

name: Johnny Brown
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Johnny Brown is a faculty member in the College of Science at Purdue University, where he is involved in both the Mathematics Graduate and Undergraduate Programs. His research interests and recent publications reflect a commitment to advancing mathematical knowledge, although specific areas of focus are not detailed in the provided text. Brown is also engaged in various academic and cultural initiatives, contributing to the diversity and inclusion within the mathematical community. He maintains an active presence in departmental activities and resources, supporting students and faculty alike.

name: Zhiqiang Cai
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Zhiqiang Cai is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in applied mathematics with a focus on neural networks, numerical partial differential equations (PDEs), adaptive methods, and computational continuum mechanics. He holds a Ph.D. from the University of Colorado and has an extensive publication record, contributing significantly to the fields of computational mathematics and numerical analysis. Cai is actively involved in teaching various courses, including numerical methods for PDEs and advanced mathematics for engineers and physicists. His research and teaching efforts are complemented by his participation in academic seminars and conferences, further enhancing the mathematical community at Purdue.

name: Giulio Caviglia
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Giulio Caviglia is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in Commutative Algebra and its intersections with Combinatorics, Computational Algebra, and Algebraic Geometry. His research contributions have advanced the understanding of these mathematical fields, and he has supervised several PhD students, including Bek Chase and Cheng Meng, as well as former students such as Yihui Liang and Anna-Rose Wolff. Caviglia is actively engaged in teaching and mentoring, fostering the next generation of mathematicians. He can be contacted via email or phone for academic inquiries.

title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics
research_description: I am interested in geometric topology, geometric group theory and dynamics. Topics I specifically studied include:

name: Marius Dadarlat
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Marius Dadarlat is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in Operator Algebras, K-theory, and Noncommutative Topology. He earned his PhD from UCLA in 1991 and has since contributed significantly to the field through his research and publications. Dadarlat is actively involved in academic activities, including organizing seminars and conferences, and he plays a key role in the Purdue Mathematics Department. His work explores complex mathematical structures and their implications, reflecting a deep engagement with both theoretical and applied aspects of mathematics.

name: Kiril Datchev
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Kiril Datchev is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in mathematical physics with a focus on spectral theory and wave equations. His research encompasses a wide range of topics, including low energy resolvent asymptotics, eigenvalue behavior, and semiclassical resonances, resulting in numerous publications in esteemed journals. Datchev has supervised PhD students and actively participates in organizing academic conferences, particularly in microlocal analysis. His contributions significantly advance the fields of analysis and partial differential equations, reflecting his expertise and commitment to mathematical research.

name: Colleen Delaney
title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics and Physics

name: Andrey Glubokov
title: Assistant Professor of Practice in Mathematics

name: David Goldberg
title: Professor of Mathematics, Director of Math Alliance
research_description: David Goldberg is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he serves as the Executive Director of the National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences. His academic interests include automorphic forms and representation theory, which he actively explores through seminars and courses. Goldberg is dedicated to fostering diversity in mathematics education and research, as evidenced by his leadership role in the Math Sciences Alliance. He is also involved in teaching undergraduate courses, contributing to the development of future mathematicians.

name: Isaac Harris
title: Barbara A. Kunze New Frontiers Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Isaac Harris is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in inverse problems and spectral methods for partial differential equations (PDEs). He earned his Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics from The University of Delaware in 2015 and previously served as a Visiting Assistant Professor at Texas A&M University. Harris's research focuses on the inverse scattering problem for non-destructive testing in complex media and parameter identification for periodic media, utilizing techniques from functional analysis, PDE analysis, and asymptotic methods. He is actively involved in the academic community, co-organizing the Spectral and Scattering Theory Seminar at Purdue and collaborating with colleagues on various research initiatives. His work is supported by NSF grants, highlighting his contributions to the field

name: Kaitlyn Hood
title: Assistant Professor of Practice in Mathematics
research_description: Kaitlyn Hood is an Assistant Professor of Practice in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where she teaches courses such as Multivariate Calculus and coordinates Data Science Labs. Her research interests include the application of mathematical principles to biological systems, exemplified by her publication on fluid flow in the sarcomere, co-authored with notable colleagues. Hood is actively engaged in the academic community, having presented her work at the Joint Math Meetings and contributing to the development of data science education. Her commitment to teaching and research reflects her dedication to advancing the intersection of mathematics and science.

name: Christopher Janjigian
title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Christopher Janjigian is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in probability theory. His research primarily investigates the infinite volume structure of random walks in random potentials (RWRP), a model that is linked to contemporary developments in probability, particularly within the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang universality class. Additionally, he explores related areas such as stochastic partial differential equations and interacting particle systems. Janjigian actively offers research opportunities for graduate students at Purdue who are interested in the field of probability.

name: Daniel Le
title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Daniel Le is a number theorist specializing in Galois representations and the Langlands program, with a strong focus on representation theory and geometry. He has held postdoctoral positions at the University of Toronto and the Institute for Advanced Study, and completed his Ph.D. at the University of Chicago. His research contributions include significant advancements in the weight part of Serre's conjecture, particularly for mod p Galois representations over CM fields, and he has co-authored numerous articles on topics such as irreducible smooth representations and Deligne-Lusztig representations. Le's work has been published in leading mathematical journals, and he actively engages in teaching linear algebra at various academic levels.

name: Victor Lie
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Victor Lie is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations, with a particular focus on Fluid Dynamics. He earned his PhD in Mathematics from UCLA in 2009. His research contributes to the understanding of complex mathematical phenomena, and he is actively engaged in advancing the field through his teaching and scholarly work.

name: Baiying Liu
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Publications and Preprints

name: Tong Liu
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Tong Liu is a faculty member specializing in Arithmetic Geometry, with a particular focus on p-adic Galois representations and integral p-adic Hodge Theory. His research contributes to the understanding of the interplay between number theory and geometry, and he has an extensive teaching portfolio that includes courses such as Math265, Math266, and Math684, among others. Liu has demonstrated a commitment to education at the University of Pennsylvania, where he has taught various undergraduate and graduate mathematics courses over the years. In addition to his academic pursuits, he enjoys sports such as swimming, ping-pong, and soccer.

name: Linquan Ma
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Linquan Ma is an Associate Professor of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in commutative algebra and algebraic geometry. He earned his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in 2014, under the supervision of Melvin Hochster. Ma's research encompasses a wide range of topics, including F-singularities, perfectoid algebras, and the minimal model program, with numerous publications in esteemed journals. He is actively involved in teaching various mathematics courses at Purdue and has contributed to the academic community through seminars and collaborative research projects. His work significantly advances the understanding of algebraic structures and their applications in mathematics.

name: Kenji Matsuki
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Kenji Matsuki is a Professor of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in algebraic geometry. His research encompasses significant topics such as the resolution of singularities, the Mori program, and the log abundance theorem, contributing to the understanding of birational transformations and minimal models. Matsuki has an extensive publication record, including influential papers in leading mathematical journals and a notable book on the Mori program. He actively engages in the academic community through collaborations and has made substantial contributions to the field of algebraic geometry.

name: Brooke Max
title: Assistant Professor of Practice in Mathematics
research_description: Brooke Max is an Assistant Professor of Practice in the Mathematics Department at Purdue University, where she focuses on the mathematical preparation of future elementary teachers. Her research interests encompass geometry, problem posing, and approximations, reflecting her commitment to enhancing mathematical understanding in education. In her role, she supports not only aspiring elementary educators but also College of Science majors fulfilling their "Great Issues" requirement, contributing to a well-rounded mathematical education.

name: Nicholas James McCleerey
title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics
research_description: This year, I am co-organizing the Geometry and Geometric Analysis Seminar at Purdue, with Lvzhou Chen. If you are interested in speaking, feel free to contact me.

name: Jeremy Miller
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Jeremy Miller is an Associate Professor at Purdue University, having previously served as a Postdoctoral Fellow at Stanford University and a Visiting Assistant Professor at the CUNY Graduate Center. His research interests lie at the intersection of algebraic topology and its applications to moduli spaces, configuration spaces, and classifying spaces. Miller has contributed to the field through various publications and preprints, showcasing his expertise and ongoing engagement with complex topological concepts. His work enhances the understanding of the relationships between algebraic topology and other mathematical structures.

name: Philip Mummert

name: Takumi Murayama
title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics
research_description: I am interested in algebraic geometry and commutative algebra, especially birational geometry and the study of singularities in all characteristics.

name: Sam Nariman
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Sam Nariman is a researcher whose work bridges homotopy theory and geometry, focusing on the applications of homotopy theory to moduli spaces of geometric structures, including foliated manifold bundles. His interests extend to homological stability, stable homology of moduli spaces, and the automorphism groups of manifolds. Nariman's research is recognized and supported by prestigious grants, including an NSF CAREER Grant and a Simons Foundation Collaboration Grant. Through his contributions, he aims to advance the understanding of complex geometric structures within the framework of homotopy theory.

name: Matthew Novack
title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Matthew Novack is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in partial differential equations with a focus on applications in fluid dynamics. His research is supported by the National Science Foundation, highlighting his contributions to the field through projects such as NSF Grant DMS-2307357. Novack has also participated in academic workshops, including the Ki-Net Young Researchers Workshop at the University of Maryland, where he presented recent findings on the 3D Quasi-Geostrophic System. His work aims to advance the understanding of complex fluid dynamics phenomena through rigorous mathematical analysis.

name: Deepam Patel
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Research: I'm mostly interested in algebraic geometry/number theory. More recently, I've become interested in some aspects of model theory and logic. You can find more information and some papers/preprintshere.

name: Jonathon Peterson
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Jonathon Peterson's web site

name: Arshak Petrosyan
title: Professor of Mathematics, Associate Department Head
research_description: Arshak Petrosyan is a Professor of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he also serves as the Associate Head of the Department of Mathematics. His research primarily focuses on partial differential equations and free boundary problems, contributing to the understanding of complex mathematical phenomena. Petrosyan has a strong academic background, having earned his PhD from the Royal Institute of Technology in Sweden, and has held various positions at Purdue since 2003. He has supervised multiple PhD students and has been actively involved in mentoring postdoctoral researchers, further enriching the academic community. His work is recognized for its depth and impact in the field of mathematics.

name: Manuel Rivera
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Manuel Rivera is a researcher specializing in algebraic topology, currently engaged in exploring the interplay between homotopical and homological techniques and their applications in geometry, topology, and algebra. He held a joint Research Assistant Professorship between the University of Miami and CINVESTAV in Mexico City from 2016 to 2019, and previously completed a postdoctoral fellowship at the Institut de Mathématiques de Jussieu in Paris. Rivera earned his PhD in mathematics from the CUNY Graduate Center in 2015, under the mentorship of Dennis Sullivan, and has a strong academic background from his undergraduate studies at MIT. His research has received support from multiple NSF grants, highlighting his contributions to the field. Originally from San Juan, Puerto

name: Antonio Sa Barreto
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Antônio Sá Barreto is a Professor of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he teaches both undergraduate and graduate courses. His research specializes in microlocal analysis and its applications to partial differential equations, geometric scattering, and spectral theory. Sá Barreto completed his Ph.D. under Richard Melrose at MIT and has supervised several doctoral students throughout his career. He is actively involved in organizing academic conferences, including sessions on nonlinear inverse problems, and has contributed to the mathematical community through numerous publications. His teaching includes courses such as Linear Algebra, Differential Equations, and Real Analysis, with resources available for students through online platforms.

name: Eric Samperton
title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics and Assistant Professor of Computer Science
research_description: Eric Samperton is a researcher whose work lies at the intersection of geometric topology and theoretical computer science. His primary interests include the relationships between low-dimensional topology, topological quantum field theories, and computational complexity, particularly in the context of quantum computing challenges like fault tolerance and quantum advantage. While much of his research is inspired by topological quantum computing, he also explores significant computational questions related to 3-dimensional manifolds, such as the homeomorphism problem, which remain unresolved. Samperton aims to contribute to a broader community effort to tackle these complex issues in topology and computation.

name: Thomas Sinclair
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Thomas Sinclair is an accomplished mathematician and faculty member at Purdue University, specializing in von Neumann algebras, ergodic theory, geometric group theory, and model theory of metric structures. His research is supported by an NSF grant and includes a robust publication record with numerous articles in esteemed journals, addressing topics such as operator systems and quantum information theory. Sinclair is actively involved in mentoring students at various academic levels, guiding them toward successful careers in mathematics. He also plays a significant role in organizing academic conferences and workshops, contributing to the advancement of research in his fields of expertise.

name: Plamen Stefanov
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Plamen Stefanov is a researcher with a focus on partial differential equations, inverse problems, and microlocal analysis. His work encompasses integral geometry and geometric analysis, with a particular interest in scattering theory and resonances, including scattering poles. Stefanov's research contributes to the understanding of complex mathematical concepts and their applications, reflecting his expertise in both theoretical and applied mathematics. His scholarly activities are supported by a robust portfolio of research projects and publications.

name: Mahesh Sunkula
title: Assistant Professor of Practice in Mathematics
research_description: Mahesh Sunkula is a researcher in applied mathematics, specializing in inverse problems, wave scattering, optimal control, and quantization. His work addresses complex mathematical challenges and seeks to develop practical solutions in these areas. Sunkula is open to mentoring undergraduate students through Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) programs, encouraging interested candidates to reach out with their CVs detailing their programming skills and relevant coursework. His research contributions aim to advance understanding and applications of mathematical concepts in real-world scenarios.

name: Margaret Thomas
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Margaret Thomas is a former Research Fellow and Associate Fellow at the Zukunftskolleg, University of Konstanz, Germany, where she contributed to various academic events and initiatives until December 2019. Although her webpage is no longer actively maintained, it serves as an archive for her involvement in organizing scholarly activities during her tenure. Her work at the Zukunftskolleg reflects her commitment to fostering academic collaboration and research development in her field.

name: Samy Tindel
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Samy Tindel is a faculty member in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in stochastic analysis and stochastic partial differential equations (PDEs). His research interests encompass fractional Brownian motion, rough paths, and the application of stochastic models in the biosciences. Tindel's work contributes to the understanding of complex stochastic processes and their implications in various scientific fields. He is actively involved in teaching and mentoring students, fostering a collaborative academic environment.

name: Andrew Toms
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Andrew Toms is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in the field of applied mathematics. His research primarily investigates the mathematical modeling of complex systems, with a focus on fluid dynamics and nonlinear partial differential equations. Toms has contributed to the understanding of turbulence and wave phenomena through his innovative approaches and has published several articles in reputable journals. He is also actively involved in mentoring students and collaborating on interdisciplinary projects that bridge mathematics with engineering and physical sciences.

name: Monica Torres
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: My research has been supported by the following grants: NSF DMS-0540869, NSF DMS-0901245, PRF Summer Faculty award (2008), PRF Travel Grant (2016), Simons Foundation Award Number 524190, NSF DMS-1813695

name: Oleksandr Tsymbaliuk
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Oleksandr Tsymbaliuk is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in Representation Theory, focusing on Cherednik algebras, quantum affine and toroidal algebras, and Yangians. His research explores the interplay between Representation Theory, Algebraic Geometry, and Integrable Systems, particularly through the lens of Laumon spaces and Nakajima quiver varieties. Tsymbaliuk's work has been supported by multiple NSF grants, reflecting his significant contributions to the field. He has previously held positions at Yale University and the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, and is also involved in a research program aimed at supporting exceptional high school students from Ukraine in honor of Yulia Zdan

name: Bernd Ulrich
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Bernd Ulrich is a faculty member in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in commutative algebra and algebraic geometry. His research encompasses a variety of topics within these fields, and he has contributed to the academic community through numerous publications and preprints. Ulrich has also played a significant role in organizing conferences, such as the Midwest Commutative Algebra and Geometry Conference, and events honoring notable mathematicians like J. Lipman. His work continues to influence the study of algebraic structures and their geometric properties.

name: Uli Walther
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Uli Walther is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he engages in teaching and research in algebra and its applications. His work encompasses a variety of topics within algebraic geometry and combinatorial algebra, contributing to the understanding of algebraic structures over time. Walther is actively involved in organizing academic conferences, such as the upcoming "Algebra Across Time" in honor of Bill Heinzer, and he has a commitment to mentoring students through research opportunities. His academic contributions are reflected in his extensive publication record, which showcases his influence in the mathematical community.

name: Jing Wang
title: Associate Professor of Mathematics and Assistant Professor of Statistics
research_description: Jing Wang is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he holds a joint appointment in Mathematics and Statistics. His research interests lie at the intersection of probability, analysis, and differential geometry, contributing to a deeper understanding of stochastic processes and their applications. Wang has previously served as a J. L. Doob Research Assistant Professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and as a postdoctoral fellow at the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications at the University of Minnesota. He earned his Ph.D. in Mathematics from Purdue University in 2014 and is actively involved in research supported by the National Science Foundation.

name: Shuyi Weng
title: Assistant Professor of Practice in Mathematics
research_description: My research interest is broadly defined within dynamical systems and computational geometry. I currently think about geometric folding problems that arise from dynamics on the complex plane.

name: Jaroslaw Wlodarczyk
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Jaroslaw Wlodarczyk is a Professor of Mathematics in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he teaches courses such as Contemporary Algebra and Differential Equations and Linear Algebra. His research primarily focuses on Birational Algebraic Geometry, particularly the resolution of singularities, foliations, and toric varieties. Wlodarczyk has contributed to the field through various publications and preprints, showcasing his expertise in these advanced mathematical concepts. His work not only enhances the academic community at Purdue but also advances the broader field of algebraic geometry.

name: Trevor Wooley
title: Andris A. Zoltners Distinguished Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Trevor Wooley is the Andris A. Zoltners Distinguished Professor of Mathematics at Purdue University, where he specializes in analytic number theory and harmonic analysis. His current research focuses on the efficient congruencing approach to Vinogradov's mean value theorem, which has led to significant advancements in understanding the optimal bounds for the number of variables needed for precise estimates. Wooley is actively involved in academic publishing, serving on the editorial boards of MATHEMATIKA and the Online Journal of Analytic Combinatorics. He has supervised numerous PhD students, many of whom have gone on to prestigious positions in academia. His contributions to the field are well-documented in a robust publication record, reflecting his influence in number theory.

name: Sai-Kee Yeung
title: Professor of Mathematics
research_description: Sai-Kee Yeung is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Purdue University, specializing in complex geometry, differential geometry, several complex variables, and algebraic geometry. He has made significant contributions to the field through his research, which includes notable publications on topics such as fake projective planes and the classification of surfaces of general type. Yeung has received several honors, including the Sloan Fellowship and the JMSJ Outstanding Paper Prize in 2013. In addition to his research, he is actively involved in teaching and mentoring students, with courses scheduled for Spring 2024, and he participates in organizing seminars related to geometric analysis. His collaborative work with other mathematicians has resulted in numerous preprints and articles in esteemed mathematical journals.
